prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Copy of CO(2-1), 2 other targets
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This contains a Spectral Setup for observations of the CO J=2-1 line at 230 GHz.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We are observing the 12CO J=2-1 line because, if only one CO line is to be observed to constrain an AGB star's gas mass loss rate, de Beck et al (2010) recommends observing this one.
We predict CO J=2-1 line flux by modeling the infrared SED of each target with GRAMS O-rich models (Sargent et al 2011). We compute a gas mass-loss rate from the dust mass-loss rate of the best model by assuming a gas-to-dust ratio of 190 (the average value for 4 OH/IR Bulge stars, determined by Sargent et al 2013). Using the formula in the Appendix of Ramstedt et al (2008) by scaling from our detection of CO J=2-1 from OH 359.943+0.260 (Sargent et al 2013), we determine the integrated CO J=2-1 line intensity from the gas mass-loss rate. Assuming an envelope expansion velocity from the separation of the two OH maser peaks (or 15.0 km/s, in the case of a non-double-peaked OH maser), we can estimate the peak CO J=2-1 line flux.
We set the sensitivity for the CO J=2-1 observations to 27 mJy, or about 1/3 the estimated CO J=2-1 peak line flux of the faintest of our targets, so that all targets will have CO J=2-1 detections with S/N of at least 3.
The spectral resolution, 0.04 km/s, is more than sufficient to resolve the CO lines for our entire sample, for which we estimate expansion velocities of 2-32 km/s based on the OH maser observations in the literature.

The spectral resolution, 0.04 km/s, is more than sufficient to resolve the CO lines for our entire sample, for which we estimate expansion velocities of 2-32 km/s based on the OH maser observations in the literature.
We require 0.2 arcsecond angular resolution so that we can resolve our targets, which are in the dense Galactic Bulge, from confusing background emission at these frequencies.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Copy of CO(3-2)+13CO(3-2), 2 other targets
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This contains a Spectral Setup for observations of the 12CO J=3-2 line at 345 GHz and the 13CO J=3-2 line at 330 GHz.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We are observing the 12CO J=3-2 line in addition to the 12CO J=2-1 because Kemper et al (2003) and Decin et al (2007) note that multiple CO lines place much better constraints on AGB gas mass loss than a single CO line alone.
We predict CO J=3-2 line flux by modeling the infrared SED of each target with GRAMS O-rich models (Sargent et al 2011). We compute a gas mass-loss rate from the dust mass-loss rate of the best model by assuming a gas-to-dust ratio of 190 (the average value for 4 OH/IR Bulge stars, determined by Sargent et al 2013). Using the formula in the Appendix of Ramstedt et al (2008) by scaling from the detection of CO J=2-1 from OH 359.943+0.260 (Sargent et al 2013), we determine the integrated CO J=2-1 line intensity from the gas mass-loss rate. Assuming an envelope expansion velocity from the separation of the two OH maser peaks (or 15.0 km/s, in the case of a non-double-peaked OH maser), we can estimate the peak CO J=2-1 line flux. Using ratios of peak CO J=3-2 to CO J=2-1 line fluxes from de Beck et al (2010) for Oxygen-rich AGB stars, we then determine the CO J=3-2 peak line flux.
We set the sensitivity for the CO J=2-1 observations to 70 mJy, or about 1/3 the estimated CO J=3-2 peak line flux of the faintest of our targets, so that all targets will have CO J=3-2 detections with S/N of at least 3.
The spectral resolution, 0.026 km/s, is more than sufficient to resolve the CO lines for our entire sample, for which we estimate expansion velocities of 2-32 km/s based on the OH maser observations in the literature.
In addition, we include the 13CO J=3-2 line because it fits within the band without asking for any additional observing time. The 13CO J=3-2 line of IK Tau had a peak main beam temperature about 7 times weaker than that of 12CO J=3-2 (Decin et al 2010), so we might expect a similar situation for our stars, perhaps detecting the brighter half in 13CO J=3-2 with S/N > 3. As multiple lines better constrain gas mass loss (Kemper et al 2003; Decin et al 2007), this line would provide even better constraints on gas mass loss. Also, there is the potential to constrain stellar nucleosynthetic processes via 13CO/12CO ratios (Wallerstein et al 2011).

The spectral resolution, 0.04 km/s, is more than sufficient to resolve the CO lines for our entire sample, for which we esimate expansion velocities of 2-32 km/s based on OH maser observations in the literature.
We require 0.2 arcsecond angular resolution so that we can resolve our Galactic Bulge targets from confusing background emission.

Using the formula in the Appendix of Ramstedt et al (2008) by scaling from our detection of CO J=2-1 from OH 359.943+0.260 (Sargent et al 2013), we determine the integrated CO J=2-1 line intensity from the gas mass-loss rate. Assuming an envelope expansion velocity from the separation of the two OH maser peaks (or 15.0 km/s, in the case of a non-double-peaked OH maser), we can estimate the peak CO J=2-1 line flux.
We set the sensitivity for the CO J=2-1 observations to 27 mJy, or about 1/3 the estimated CO J=2-1 peak line flux of the faintest of our targets, so that all targets will have CO J=2-1 detections with S/N of at least 3.
The spectral resolution, 0.04 km/s, is more than sufficient to resolve the CO lines for our entire sample, for which we estimate expansion velocities of 2-32 km/s based on the OH maser observations in the literature.
The spectral resolution, 0.04 km/s, is more than sufficient to resolve CO lines for our entire sample.
We require 0.2 arcsecond angular resolution so that we can resolve Galactic Bulge targets from confusing background emission.

We are observing the 12CO J=3-2 line in addition to the 12CO J=2-1 because Kemper et al (2003) and Decin et al (2007) note that multiple CO lines place much better constraints on AGB gas mass loss than a single CO line alone.
We predict CO J=3-2 line flux by modeling the infrared SED of each target with GRAMS O-rich models (Sargent et al 2011). Using the formula in the Appendix of Ramstedt et al (2008) by scaling from the detection of CO J=2-1 from OH 359.943+0.260 (Sargent et al 2013), we determine the integrated CO J=2-1 line intensity from the gas mass-loss rate. Assuming an envelope expansion velocity from the separation of the two OH maser peaks (or 15.0 km/s, in the case of a non-double-peaked OH maser), we can estimate the peak CO J=2-1 line flux. Using ratios of peak CO J=3-2 to CO J=2-1 line fluxes from de Beck et al (2010) for Oxygen-rich AGB stars, we then determine the CO J=3-2 peak line flux.
We set the sensitivity for the CO J=2-1 observations to 70 mJy, or about 1/3 the estimated CO J=3-2 peak line flux of the faintest of our targets, so that all targets will have CO J=3-2 detections with S/N of at least 3.

In addition, we include the 13CO J=3-2 line because it fits within the band without asking for any additional observing time. The 13CO J=3-2 line of IK Tau had a peak main beam temperature about 7 times weaker than that of 12CO J=3-2 (Decin et al 2010), so we might expect a similar situation for our stars, perhaps detecting the brighter half in 13CO J=3-2 with S/N > 3. Also, there is the potential to constrain stellar nucleosynthetic processes via 13CO/12CO ratios (Wallerstein et al 2011).
The spectral resolution is more than sufficient to resolve the CO lines for our entire sample.
We require 0.2 arcsecond angular resolution so that we can resolve our Galactic Bulge targets from confusing background emission.

We predict CO J=2-1 line flux by modeling the infrared SED of each target with GRAMS O-rich models (Sargent et al 2011). prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Copy of CO(3-2)+13CO(3-2), set B2 of 5
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This contains a Spectral Setup for observations of the 12CO J=3-2 line at 345 GHz and the 13CO J=3-2 line at 330 GHz.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We are observing the 12CO J=3-2 line in addition to the 12CO J=2-1 because Kemper et al (2003) and Decin et al (2007) note that multiple CO lines place much better constraints on AGB gas mass loss than a single CO line alone.
We predict CO J=3-2 line flux by modeling the infrared SED of each target with GRAMS O-rich models (Sargent et al 2011). We compute a gas mass-loss rate from the dust mass-loss rate of the best model by assuming a gas-to-dust ratio of 190 (the average value for 4 OH/IR Bulge stars, determined by Sargent et al 2013). Using the formula in the Appendix of Ramstedt et al (2008) by scaling from the detection of CO J=2-1 from OH 359.943+0.260 (Sargent et al 2013), we determine the integrated CO J=2-1 line intensity from the gas mass-loss rate. Assuming an envelope expansion velocity from the separation of the two OH maser peaks (or 15.0 km/s, in the case of a non-double-peaked OH maser), we can estimate the peak CO J=2-1 line flux. Using ratios of peak CO J=3-2 to CO J=2-1 line fluxes from de Beck et al (2010) for Oxygen-rich AGB stars, we then determine the CO J=3-2 peak line flux.
We set the sensitivity for the CO J=2-1 observations to 70 mJy, or about 1/3 the estimated CO J=3-2 peak line flux of the faintest of our targets, so that all targets will have CO J=3-2 detections with S/N of at least 3.
The spectral resolution, 0.026 km/s, is more than sufficient to resolve the CO lines for our entire sample, for which we estimate expansion velocities of 2-32 km/s based on the OH maser observations in the literature.
In addition, we include the 13CO J=3-2 line because it fits within the band without asking for any additional observing time. The 13CO J=3-2 line of IK Tau had a peak main beam temperature about 7 times weaker than that of 12CO J=3-2 (Decin et al 2010), so we might expect a similar situation for our stars, perhaps detecting the brighter half in 13CO J=3-2 with S/N > 3. As multiple lines better constrain gas mass loss (Kemper et al 2003; Decin et al 2007), this line would provide even better constraints on gas mass loss. Also, there is the potential to constrain stellar nucleosynthetic processes via 13CO/12CO ratios (Wallerstein et al 2011).
The spectral resolution is more than sufficient to resolve the CO lines for our entire sample.
We require 0.2 arcsecond resolution so that we can resolve our Galactic Bulge targets from confusing background emission.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to use ALMA to detect the CO J=2-1 (230 GHz) and 3-2 (345 GHz) lines from the envelopes of OH/IR stars in the inner Galactic bulge region. This is impossible with a single-dish instrument due to the extended emission from interstellar molecular clouds. The data will be used to estimate the mass-loss rates of these stars to get a picture of the replenishment of the ISM in the inner bulge.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: Winnberg et al. 2011 Sargent et al. 2011 Sargent et al. 2012 Sargent et al. 2013
